TEXT: The applicants , PERSON and PERSON , are NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively . They are married and live in GPE , GPE . They are represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicants applied to ORG ) for an allocation of a flat in which they had been living since DATE .
On DATE the Head of FAC ( PERSON Lokalowych Urzędu PERSON ) dismissed the application . The applicant appealed against this decision .
In the meantime , the applicants lodged complaints about the inactivity of the administrative authorities .
On DATE the Head of ORG of ORG ( PERSON ) refused to allocate the flat to the first applicant . The applicants appealed .
On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) quashed the impugned decision and remitted the case for reexamination .
On DATE the Mayor of ORG ) stayed the proceedings . The applicants appealed against this decision .
On DATE ORG resumed the proceedings .
On DATE the Head of ORG of ORG refused to allocate the flat to the first applicant . The applicants appealed against this decision .
On DATE ORG of Appeal quashed the impugned decision and discontinued the proceedings . The applicants lodged a complaint with ORG ( PERSON ) .
On DATE ORG quashed the both impugned decisions of DATE and of CARDINAL DATE .
On DATE the Head of ORG of ORG discontinued the proceedings concerning the allocation of the flat to the applicants . The applicants appealed .
On DATE ORG dismissed their appeal .

LAW lays down timelimits ranging DATE for dealing with a case pending before an administrative authority . If those time - limits have not been complied with , the authority must , under LAW , inform the parties of that fact , explain the reasons for the delay and fix a new time - limit . Pursuant to LAW , if the case has not been handled within the time - limits referred to in ORG and DATE , a party to administrative proceedings can lodge an appeal to the higher authority , alleging inactivity . In cases where the allegations of inactivity are well - founded , the higher authority fixes a new term for handling the case and orders an inquiry in order to determine the reasons for the inactivity and to identify the persons responsible for the delay . If need be , the authority may order that measures preventing future such delays be applied .
Until DATE , under LAW , a party to administrative proceedings could , at any time , lodge with ORG a complaint about the fact that an administrative authority had failed to issue a decision .
On DATE , when a new LAW DATE on ORG ( “ the DATE LAW ) took effect , LAW was repealed .
Under LAW , a party to administrative proceedings may , at any time , lodge with ORG a complaint against inactivity on the part of an authority obliged to issue an administrative decision .
Section CARDINAL of the PERSON provides :

“ When a complaint alleging inactivity on the part of an administrative authority is well - founded , ORG shall oblige that authority to issue a decision , or to perform a specific act , or to confirm , declare , or recognise a right or obligation provided for by law . ”

Pursuant to LAW , the decision of ORG ordering an authority to put an end to its inactivity is legally binding on the authority concerned . If the authority has not complied with the decision , the court may , under section CARDINAL of the DATE Act , impose a fine on it and may itself give a ruling on the right or obligation in question .
